'''Wayne Darwen''' is an Australian journalist, television producer and filmmaker best known for his work in the [[tabloid television]] genre<ref>[http://tabloidbaby.blogspot.com/1999/11/ny-post-my-fondest-affair-when-we-were_14.html Tabloid Baby]</ref> and as director and star of the film, ''[[High There]]'' (2015).<ref name=AP>[http://www.anchoragepress.com/film/high-there Anchorage Press]</ref>
Began career as a 17-year-old reporter for a newspaper in [[Sydney, Australia]]. He worked internationally as a reporter for titles such as ''[[Sydney Daily Mirror]]'', ''[[Star (magazine)|Star]]'' magazine and the ''[[New York Post]]'', before moving to American television as a producer of tabloid [[newsmagazine]] shows like ''[[A Current Affair (U.S. TV series)|A Current Affair]]'', ''[[Hard Copy]]'', [[Geraldo Rivera]]’s ''Now It Can be Told'',<ref>[http://www.hollywood.com/tv/55070352/now-it-can-be-told?page=219 Hollywood.com]</ref> ''[[Strange Universe]]'' and ''[[Inside Edition]]''.<ref>[http://observer.com/1999/12/steve-dunleavy-and-the-rise-of-tabloid-tv/ New York Observer]</ref>
He received attention for his 1993 series of televised interviews with [[Son of Sam]] killer [[David Berkowitz]],<ref>[http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/columns/intelligencer/1115/ New York Magazine]</ref> in which Berkowitz claimed the murders were the work of a Satanic cult.<ref>[https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1320&dat=19931113&id=_Xw1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=XOoDAAAAIBAJ&pg=4332,4378381 Google News]</ref> He appeared as reporter in the documentary film, ''Dark Mirror of Magick: The Vassago Millennium Prophecy'' (2012).<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GqP00mgUFvY YouTube]</ref>
His early television exploits were featured in the 1999 book ''[[Tabloid Baby]]'',<ref>[http://www.salon.com/1999/12/08/tabloid/ Salon.com]</ref> written by his colleague [[Burt Kearns]].
==''Natural Born Killers''==
Darwen inspired the character of newsman Wayne Gale, portrayed by [[Robert Downey Jr.]] in [[Oliver Stone]]’s film, ''[[Natural Born Killers]]'' (1994).<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=42W9Uf2gTXI YouTube]</ref><ref>[https://www.amazon.com/Tabloid-Baby-Burt-Kearns/dp/1580291074 Amazon.com]</ref><ref name=P6>[http://pagesix.com/2015/05/20/robert-downey-jr-was-more-interesting-on-drugs/ Pagesix.com]</ref>
In May 2015, Darwen made international news when he responded to Downey's attack on journalists<ref>[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2015/04/22/robert-downey-jr-walks-out-interview_n_7120716.html The Huffington Post]</ref> and independent films,<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/may/01/robert-downey-jr-indie-movies-exhausting-and-sometimes-suck The Guardian]</ref> telling ''[[The New York Post]]''{{'}}s Page Six: "Junior was a lot more interesting when he was a substance-abusing, suffering artist — brave and silly enough to push the envelope."<ref name=P6/>
==''High There''== Darwen wrote, directed (with [[Henry Goren]]), produced and took on the guise of Dave High<ref>[http://mysteriesfrombeyond.blogspot.com/2015/01/the-mind-boggling-power-of-marijuana.html Mysteries From Beyond]</ref> in the documentary film ''[[High There]]'' (2015).<ref>[http://pagesix.com/2014/08/18/tabloid-producer-darwen-about-to-have-doc-hit-festival-circuit/ Pagesix.com]</ref> ''High There'' is a nonfiction comedy about the efforts of Darwen and [[Henry Goren]] to film the pilot for a marijuana travelogue series on the island of Hawaii. They wind up in various misadventures, while uncovering a [[Drug Enforcement Administration]] campaign to control the marijuana trade and to persecute marijuana activist [[Roger Christie]].<ref>[http://www.hawaiinewsnow.com/story/26628600/hilos-pot-minister-speaks-out-after-prison-release Hawaiinewsnow.com]</ref> It is the first leg of a filmic journey that picks up where Darwen's colleague and inspiration [[Hunter S. Thompson]] left off.<ref>[http://www.laweekly.com/music/gonzo-style-documentary-high-there-explores-pot-legalization-battle-in-hawaii-5665470 LA Weekly]</ref>
''High There'' premiered 25 August 2014 at the [[Action on Film International Film Festival]] in Monrovia, California. Darwen was on location in [[Adelaide]] at the time, so he appeared at the premiere as a life-size cardboard cut-out.<ref>[http://hightherethemovie.blogspot.com/2014/08/high-there-storms-action-on-film.html High the Movie]</ref> The film won the Viewers' Choice Award at the first annual Cannabis Film Festival in Humboldt County, California on May 3, 2015.<ref>[http://www.420magazine.com/forums/420-documentaries/246179-high-there-wins-viewers-choice-award-1st-cannabis-film-festival.html 420magazine.com]</ref> On the heels of several rave reviews,<ref name=AP/> it was released on VOD and Limited Edition DVD<ref>[https://www.amazon.com/High-There-Wayne-Darwen/dp/B00U2YNLK0 Amazon.com]</ref> by [[BrinkVision]]<ref>[http://www.brinkvision.com Brinkvision.com]</ref> on June 23, 2015.<ref>[http://www.hightherethemovie.com Hightherethemovie.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.theaustralian.com.au/business/media/wayne-darwens-high-there-stoners-film-is-a-labour-of-love/story-e6frg9tf-1227358238524 The Australian]</ref><ref>[http://www.abucketofcorn.com/2015/07/brink-vision-dvd-high-there-2014.html Abucketofcorn.com]</ref>
